label: Can I just do a maintenance instead of a service call to save money?
answerText: Maintenance is preventative; a service call is for diagnosing a problem. Are you having symptoms right now?
followUpQuestion: Are you having symptoms right now?

label: If maintenance is the same price, I'd rather do that
answerText: I get it—maintenance is great when everything's running normally; diagnostics fit active issues. What's it doing today?

label: AC stopped, but maybe a tune-up will get it going again
answerText: A tune-up helps performance, but a no-cool needs problem identification first. Is it blowing warm or not running?
followUpQuestion: Is it blowing warm or not running?

label: Acting up, but I want maintenance because feels like more value
answerText: Totally fair—maintenance adds care, but diagnostics find the exact failure causing trouble. Is this intermittent or constant?

label: Haven't serviced it in forever, so maybe maintenance fixes it
answerText: Skipped maintenance can contribute, but rough operation usually needs a proper diagnostic. Any strange noises or smells?

label: Like a car—if I do the oil change now, it'll probably be fine
answerText: Great analogy—maintenance helps prevent damage, but once it's running rough, we diagnose. Is cooling weak or fully out?
followUpQuestion: Is cooling weak or fully out?

label: Don't want a service call fee if you're not fixing anything
answerText: The service visit is what finds the cause and options; repairs come after approval. What problem are you noticing most?
followUpQuestion: What problem are you noticing most?

label: Can you just come do maintenance and if you find something, tell me?
answerText: We can, but if you're calling for a specific issue, diagnostics is the cleaner route. Is this a comfort problem or routine?
followUpQuestion: Is this a comfort problem or routine?

label: It started working again, so maybe I should just do maintenance
answerText: If it recovered, maintenance is smart; if it's failing intermittently, diagnosis prevents repeats. How often has it happened?

label: Trying not to spend more than I have to—maintenance sounds safer
answerText: I respect that—right service type avoids wasted visits: maintenance for prevention, diagnostic for symptoms. What's the main symptom today?

label: System is not cooling—can I schedule a maintenance instead?
answerText: If it's not cooling, that's an active issue and diagnostics fits best. Is it blowing warm or just weak?
followUpQuestion: Is it blowing warm or just weak?

label: AC is not cooling, but I just want a maintenance visit
answerText: I understand—maintenance is preventative, but no-cool needs the cause identified first. Is the whole house affected?

label: System isn't cooling at all; can you put me down for maintenance?
answerText: For no-cool, we treat it as a service diagnosis so nothing gets missed. Is it running but warm?

label: Unit is running and not cooling—schedule me for maintenance please
answerText: Got it—when it runs but won't cool, diagnostics is the right visit type. Any unusual sounds or smells?

label: House is hot, system not cooling; I want the $89 maintenance
answerText: I hear you—maintenance won't reliably address a no-cool complaint without diagnosis. Is airflow strong from the vents?
followUpQuestion: Is airflow strong from the vents?

label: Can I book a maintenance even though the AC isn't cooling?
answerText: We can schedule the correct visit so you get answers, not guesswork. Is it completely warm air?

label: Not cooling—I want a tune-up instead of a service call
answerText: A tune-up helps when it's operating normally; no-cool needs targeted diagnosis first. When did it start?

label: Not cooling—just schedule a maintenance and check it out
answerText: Alright — hang with me for a moment.
followUpQuestion: Is it short-cycling or running nonstop?

label: Not cooling but it's same price so I'd rather do maintenance
answerText: Totally understandable—same price, different purpose; diagnostics finds the failure causing no-cool. Any breaker trips?

label: Air conditioner is not cooling; can you schedule maintenance for me?
answerText: We'll take care of you—when it's not cooling, we schedule a diagnostic to identify the issue. One system or two?

label: Why can't I just schedule a maintenance?
answerText: Maintenance and diagnostic visits are routed differently; troubleshooting techs carry different tools and parts. What symptom are you having?

label: Same price—why won't you just put it as maintenance?
answerText: Different appointment types use different tech assignments and truck stock; diagnostics is built for problem-solving. Is it not cooling?

label: Aren't all your technicians the same? Why not maintenance?
answerText: They're all experienced, but some are scheduled for preventive work, not active troubleshooting. Is your system currently acting up?
followUpQuestion: Is your system currently acting up?

label: Just want maintenance—why do you keep saying service call?
answerText: Maintenance crews focus on tune-ups; diagnostic techs are dispatched for failures and carry the right repair-ready inventory. What's it doing?

label: Why does it matter what you label it as?
answerText: Labels control routing, time blocks, and what's on the truck; diagnostics avoids wasted trips. Is it a comfort issue today?
followUpQuestion: Is it a comfort issue today?

label: Can't a maintenance tech just figure it out while they're there?
answerText: Sometimes, but maintenance schedules and equipment aren't built for deeper troubleshooting. Better to send the right tech first. Is it no-cool?

label: Don't see the difference—maintenance should cover it
answerText: Maintenance is preventive checks; diagnostics is targeted testing for a specific problem and often needs different parts. What problem started this call?

label: So you're telling me maintenance techs can't fix problems?
answerText: They can handle many basics, but complex troubleshooting is routed to diagnostic techs with specialized testing focus. What symptom are you seeing?

label: Why can't you just send whoever is available?
answerText: Sending the wrong visit type can delay resolution; the right technician and parts matter. Is the system running but not cooling?
followUpQuestion: Is the system running but not cooling?

label: I still want maintenance—why can't you schedule it anyway?
answerText: We want to solve it fast, not guess—diagnostic scheduling matches troubleshooting skills and truck inventory. Is this urgent no-cool?
